docs.lead_paragraph: It's been bad a year for European mergers and acquisitions.

headline.main: The Sad State of European Deal-Making

docs.abstract: M.&A. activity on the Continent in 2010 will account for the smallest slice of global deal-making in more than a decade.
docs.snippet: M.&A. activity on the Continent in 2010 will account for the smallest slice of global deal-making in more than a decade.

docs.lead_paragraph: As obesity rates continue to rise, more and more people are seeking surgery for weight loss. From 1998 to 2004, the number of bariatric operations performed in the United States rose 804 percent. While insurance may cover much of the expense of surgery, the high costs of care following the operation often catch patients by surprise. Lesley Alderman explains in today's Patient Money column:
docs.abstract: As more and more people consider surgery for weight loss, it's important to calculate all of the associated costs before deciding whether it's the right choice for you.
docs.snippet: As more and more people consider surgery for weight loss, it's important to calculate all of the associated costs before deciding whether it's the right choice for you.

docs.lead_paragraph: The concept of a "holiday" is an elusive one for the over 28 million people in the United States who provide care for someone age 75 or older. A 2009 National Alliance for Caregiving/AARP study found that 88 percent of family caregivers never get a break from this full-time job. As readers here know all too well, the non-stop effort can take both a physical and emotional toll over time.
docs.abstract: With federal assistance, two dozen states have taken tentative steps toward building respite programs for caregivers.
docs.snippet: With federal assistance, two dozen states have taken tentative steps toward building respite programs for caregivers.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a year of highs and lows for President Obama, who finally got a health care overhaul passed but got a "shellacking" from voters as the economic recovery stalled. Republicans seized control of the House but fell short in the Senate as underdogs like Harry Reid, the embattled majority leader, held on. And the Tea Party became something more than an idea, if not quite an organized political movement.

headline.main: Times Readers' Top Political Moments of 2010

docs.abstract: We asked for your key political moments of 2010, and you answered. A sampling of your top picks.
docs.snippet: We asked for your key political moments of 2010, and you answered. A sampling of your top picks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tales that wrap themselves into neat packages with pretty bows are the exception in life, not the norm. The parenting tale, in particular, is a perpetual one, and year-end updates are more likely to be chapters rather than endings.
docs.abstract: Not every story has a happy ending. Or even an ending.
docs.snippet: Not every story has a happy ending. Or even an ending.

docs.lead_paragraph: As members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 65, they may need to re-examine the notion that “age is just a number.”

headline.main: Real Life Among the Old Old
headline.print_headline: Real Life Among the Old Old

docs.snippet: As members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 65, they may need to re-examine the notion that “age is just a number.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Irish law prohibits all abortions except those necessary to save a woman's life, and as a practical matter it imposes daunting obstacles to terminating life-threatening pregnancies as well. In a secularized Europe, Ireland is noticeably out of step. Of the 47 countries covered by the European Convention on Human Rights, only in the fairytale countries of Andorra, Malta and San Marino, where all abortions are illegal, is the law any stricter.
docs.abstract: A European court's decision on abortion, and its parallels to the United States.
docs.snippet: A European court's decision on abortion, and its parallels to the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: Part-time work in the Netherlands has turned from being the prerogative of women into a powerful tool to attract talent in a competitive labor market.

headline.print_headline:
Flexible Workweek Alters
The Rhythm of Dutch Life

docs.snippet: Part-time work in the Netherlands has turned from being the prerogative of women into a powerful tool to attract talent in a competitive labor market.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last two years, it has been widely reported that small businesses create more jobs than big businesses and thus are critical to the recovery. It has also been widely reported that small businesses are getting squeezed -- by the credit freeze, by skyrocketing costs like health and unemployment insurance, and by cheap imports, to name a few examples.

headline.main: Are Small Businesses Going to Be Saviors or Victims?

docs.abstract: The small businesses that succeed will need to do more than just hope. And they will need to do more than just complain about the government and wait for it to solve all problems.
docs.snippet: The small businesses that succeed will need to do more than just hope. And they will need to do more than just complain about the government and wait for it to solve all problems.
